metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Rust If .. Else Conditions
Conditions and If..Else
You have already learned that Rust supports the usual logical conditions from mathematics:
content.html: You have already learned that Rust supports the usual logical conditions from mathematics:

content.text: You can use these conditions to perform different actions for different decisions.
content.html: You can use these conditions to perform different actions for different decisions.

content.text: Rust has the following conditional statements:

Note: Unlike many other programming languages, if..else can be used as a statement or as an expression (to assign a value to a variable) in Rust. See an example at the bottom of the page to better understand it.
content.html: Note: Unlike many other programming languages, if..else can be used as a statement or as an expression (to assign a value to a variable) in Rust. See an example at the bottom of the page to better understand it.

content.text: if
Use if to specify a block of code to be executed if a condition is true .
content.html: Use if to specify a block of code to be executed if a condition is true.

content.code_html:
if 7 > 5 {
  println!("7 is greater than 5.");
}

content.text: You can also test variables:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let x = 7;let y = 5;if x > y {  println!("x is greater 
  than y.");}

content.code:
let x = 7;let y = 5;if x > y {  println!("x is greater
than y.");}

syntax_highlighting.text:
let x = 7;let y = 5;if x > y {  println!("x is greater 
  than y.");}

content.code_html:
let x = 7;
let y = 5;

if x > y {
  println!("x is greater than y.");
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let x = 7;let y = 5;if x > y {  println!("x is greater 
  than y.");}

content.text: if...else
If the condition is not true, you can use else to run different code:
content.html: If the condition is not true, you can use else to run different code:

content.code_html:
let age = 16;

if age >= 18 {
  println!("You can vote.");
} else {
  println!("You are too young to vote.");
}

content.text: else if
You can check multiple conditions using else if :
content.html: You can check multiple conditions using else if:

content.code_html:
let score = 85;

if score >= 90 {
  println!("Grade: A");
} else if score >= 80 {
  println!("Grade: B");
} else if score >= 70 {
  println!("Grade: C");
} else {
  println!("Grade: F");
}

content.text: Using if as an Expression
In Rust, if...else can also be used as an expression .
content.html: In Rust, if...else can also be used as an expression.

content.text: This means you can assign the result of an if to a variable:
content.html: This means you can assign the result of an if to a variable:

content.code_html:
let time = 20;
let greeting = if time < 18 {
  "Good day."
} else {
  "Good evening."
};
println!("{}", greeting);

content.text: When using if as an expression, you must include else . This ensures the result always has a value.
content.html: When using if as an expression, you must include else . This ensures the result always has a value.

content.text: Simplified Syntax
If each block only contains one line, you can remove the curly braces {} and write it in a shorter way:
content.html: If each block only contains one line, you can remove the curly braces {} and write it in a shorter way:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let time = 20;let greeting = if time < 18 { "Good day." } else { "Good 
  evening." };println!("{}", greeting);

content.code:
let time = 20;let greeting = if time < 18 { "Good day." } else { "Good
evening." };println!("{}", greeting);

syntax_highlighting.text:
let time = 20;let greeting = if time < 18 { "Good day." } else { "Good 
  evening." };println!("{}", greeting);

content.code_html:
let time = 20;
let greeting = if time < 18 { "Good day." } else { "Good evening." };
println!("{}", greeting);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let time = 20;let greeting = if time < 18 { "Good day." } else { "Good 
  evening." };println!("{}", greeting);

content.text: Note: The value from if and else must be the same type, like two pieces of text or two numbers (in our example, both are strings).
content.html: Note: The value from if and else must be the same type, like two pieces of text or two numbers (in our example, both are strings).

content.text: Tip: This example works similarly to the ternary operator (short-hand if...else ) in languages like Java or C .
content.html: Tip: This example works similarly to the ternary operator (short-hand if...else) in languages like Java or C.
